Article.ArticleTitle: Ozone/peroxide advanced oxidation in combination with biofiltration for taste and odour control and organics removal.

AbstractText: The objective of this pilot-scale study was to investigate the effectiveness of incorporating ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) and advanced oxidation (hydrogen peroxide/ozone: H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>/O<sub>3</sub>) in combination with biofiltration for taste and odour control, organic carbon removal, and disinfection byproduct (DBP) precursor reduction. Implementation of O<sub>3</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> with and without biofiltration was investigated at pilot-scale in terms of geosmin, 2-methylisoborneol (MIB), and DBP precursor removal efficiency. Two media types (granular activated carbon and anthracite) were compared in conjunction with investigating the impact of pre-oxidation with O<sub>3</sub> (2 mg/L) and varying H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> mass ratios (0.1, 0.2, 0.35, and 0.5 mg/mg). When O<sub>3</sub> preceded biologically active carbon (BAC) or biologically active anthracite, geosmin removals of 80% and 81%, respectively, were observed at 10 °C; this increased to 89% and 90%, respectively, at 16 °C. Optimal MIB removal (67%) was achieved with 0.1 H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> (mg/mg) in combination with BAC at 16 °C. In general, geosmin proved to be more amenable to biodegradation than MIB. BAC without pre-oxidation removed 87% geosmin and 85% MIB, at 22 °C. MIB removals decreased to 60% and 46%, respectively at 16 °C and 10 °C. The application of 0.2 H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> (mg/mg) prior to BAC provided treatment which effectively removed geosmin and MIB. However, in terms of DBP precursor reduction, there was no beneficial impact of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> addition on trihalomethane or haloacetic acid formation potentials.
